I believe it's proper to use a comma between each separate group of three or more.
 
 Here's a good reason why, as explained in the Blue Book of Grammar:
 
 Rule 1. To avoid confusion, use commas to separate words and word groups with a series of three or more. 
 Example: My $10,000,000 estate is to be split among my husband, daughter, son, and nephew. 
 
 Without the comma between son and nephew, the 10 million would be split just three ways. With the comma the correct understanding of her wishes are known.

 Regarding redundancy: The English section of the ACT has questions on redundancy. My old English teacher's ACT mantra was "Thou shalt not be redundant over again repeatedly." If you plan to take the ACT, be wary of redundancy.
 
 Regarding "matching" lists/series: The English section of the ACT has questions on this topic. You often will have to correct a list of that type by making all three items match in form: Correcting for redundancy, "He likes to [bike], skateboard, and go swimming," becomes "He likes to [bike], skateboard, and swim."

 That's strange. To go swimming is perfectly fine grammar-wise. German has similar verbs, like einkaufen gehen, which is literally "to go shopping." It's incorrect without the gehen. "I'm going shopping," for instance, is does not mean the same thing as "I'm shopping." The latter implies I am already in the process of shopping, while the former says I have to actually start shopping. The same principle applies to "swimming" versus "going swimming".

"He likes to swim, skateboard, and go swimming."
 
 One problem may be a missing "to" before skateboard and "go swimming".
 
 The comma before "and" is required by Warriner's English Grammar from the 1980s, but when I was in grade school during the 1970s this comma was not needed and I used Warriner's only in the 7th grade (1981-1982). A comma before the "and" that connects a last item to a series may be more a matter of style than grammar. I don't use it because I was not taught to use it. 
 
 The sentence is also badly written. "To swim" and "go swimming" are redundant. But, when you want to use multiple verbs it's best to keep them in the same form: "He likes swimming, skateboarding and swimming." The original version mixes verb infinitives and participles, so it sounds awkward; use all infinitives or all participles.

Flaja kind of said this, but here goes. If you wanted to use "to go swimming", the sentence would have to be: He likes to go swimming, to go skateboarding, and to go swimming. If you wanted to use "to swim", the sentence would have to say: "He likes to swim, to skateboard, and to swim". On this, "to swim" is the infinitive, and so you must make the others into the infinitive. Like prevously mentioned, this is called parallelism. It just means that everything in the sentence has to be constructed the same. Wiki explains it better here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallelism_%28grammar%29
 
 In my opinion the best way to say that sentence(ignoring the redundancy) would be: "He likes swimming, skateboarding, and swimming."
